title: Can two cations or two anions bond? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, there are many examples of this. For example, ionic monomers can polymerize such that two cationic monomers or two anionic monomers can react to form a dimer as the first step in formation of a polymer. For example, acrylic acid can be polymerized to form polyacrylic acid and vinylbenzyltrimethylammonium chloride can be polymerized to form a polybenzyltrimethylammonium chloride. There are also examples of condensation reactions that have the same effect. For example, phosphoric acid when heated can be condensed to form pyrophosphoric acid.

All cations can form bonds - just not with other cations. All anions can form bonds - just not with other anions. Cations have a + charge which repels other cations with a + charge and the same logic applies to the - charge on the anion. However, the + of the cation WILL attract the - of the anion. Having said this, you can have two cations bonded to a single anion but once again, the cations are not bonded to each other.
No - think electrostatics about like and unlike charges.
It is unlikely because atoms are drawn towards the “opposites attract” notion. a partial charge that’s negative is drawn towards the partial positive and vice versa.
